sack.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a large bag made of strong rough cloth or strong paper, used for storing or carrying flour, coal, vegetables etc
sack.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the amount that a sack can contain
sack.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We need about a sack of rice.
sack.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to dismiss someone from their job
sack.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: They couldn’t sack me – I’d done nothing wrong.
He was sacked from every other job he had.
He was sacked for being drunk.
sack.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: In written and formal British English, people often prefer to use dismiss rather than sack:
People can be dismissed for misusing the Internet at work.
sack.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to knock down the quarterback in American football
sack.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: if soldiers sack a place, they go through it destroying or stealing things and attacking people
sack.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to be dismissed from your job or to dismiss someone from their job
sack.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: He got the sack for stealing.
